Identifying Characteristics: Mainly black in color, but can sometimes be blueish-black, dark grey, dark green, or dark brown
Two uneven rows of yellowish-orange spots run down the entire top of the body
Spots near the top of the head are more orange and the spots on the rest of the body are more yellow
Underside is gray and pink Larvae are usually light brown or greenish-yellow
Larvae are usually light brown or greenish-yellow
Larvae have small dark spots and are born with external gills
Size: Adults can reach up to 9” in length but are typically about 7”
Biology: Cannot breed in permanent pools because fish inhabiting the pools would eat the eggs and larvae
Only come above ground after a rain or for foraging and breeding
During winter they hibernate underground, and are not seen again until breeding season in early March–May
Mates usually breed in ponds when it is raining in the spring
Females lay about 100 eggs that cling to the underwater vegetation
Eggs are round, clear, jelly-like clumps that are usually 2.5–4 in long
The eggs hatch in one to two months
Eggs can have a symbiotic relationship with green algae and photosynthetic algae are present within the somatic and possibly the germ cells of the salamander
Hatch time depends on the water temperatures
After larvae develop (in two to four months) the larvae lose their gills and become juvenile salamanders and leave the water
Life span: can live up to 32 years
Habitat: Moist and low-lying forests near floodplains
In burrows or under leaf litters
Hardwood forest areas with vernal pools
Spend most of their time underground
Diet: Crickets, worms, insects, spiders, slugs, centipedes, millipedes
Range: Eastern Canada and eastern and Midwest United States
